dataset.title: Meteorology Data at the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge, New Mexico, 1990

address.deliveryPoint: Sevilleta LTER, 167 Castetter Hall, University of New Mexico
Sevilleta LTER, 167 Castetter Hall, University of New Mexico

section.para: This file contains the weather data for a network of 7 permanent weather stations on the Sevilleta Wildlife area and Langmuir Labs for the year 1990.

para.literalLayout: This file contains the weather data for a network of 7 permanent weather stations on the Sevilleta Wildlife area and Langmuir Labs for the year 1990. Station 40 has been in operation since the middle of 1987; Stations 41-44 were installed in the early part of 1989; Station 45 was put into operation on 26 Jan 1990 (hour 15); and Station 46 as put into operation on 31 Aug 1990 (hour 17). The geographic locations of the various weather stations are as follows:40 = Deep Well Site: Lat 34.3556, Long -106.691441 = South Gate Site: 34.2177, -106.795842 = Cerro Montosa Site: 34.3692, -106.534143 = Watersheds Site: 34.3892, -107.039844 = Rio Salado Site: 34.3489, -106.880245 = Bronco Well Site: 34.4068, -106.932846 = Langmuir Site: 33.97472 -107.1808 Note that Stations 40, 45, and 46 are the only stations that collect data on solar radiation.

This dataset is released to the public and may be freely downloaded. Please keep the designated Contact person informed of any plans to use the dataset. Consultation or collaboration with the original investigators is strongly encouraged. Publications and data products that make use of the dataset must include proper acknowledgement of the Sevilleta LTER. Datasets must be cited as in the example below.
Muldavin, E. 2004. Sevilleta LTER Fertilizer NPP Study Dataset. Albuquerque, NM: Sevilleta Long Term Ecological Research Site Database: SEV155. (Date of download)
A copy of any publications using these data must be supplied to the Sevilleta LTER Information Manager.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription:
Location: Deep Well is located on McKenzie Flats and is site of the longest running SEV LTER met station, number 40, which has been active since 1988. In addition to studies of meteorological variables, core line-intercept vegetation transects and line-intercept transects from the 1995 and 2001 Deep Well fires are sampled here. The mini-rhizotron study, blue and black grama compositional comparison, blue and black grama patch dynamics investigation, and kangaroo rat population assessement are all ongoing here. Deep Well Blue/Black Grama Mixed is also the location of the warming and monsoon experiments, as well as portions of the line-intercept and vegetation removal studies. On August 4, 2009, a lightning-initiated fire began on the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge. By August 5, 2009, the fire had reached the area of Deep Well Blue/Black Grama Mixed. While portions of this site were burned, the entirety was not. See individual projects for further information on the effects of the fire.Vegetation: The vegetation of Deep Well Blue/Black Grama Mixed is Chihuahuan Desert Grassland, dominated by black grama (Bouteloua eriopoda) and blue grama (B. gracilis). Other grasses found at the site include dropseeds (Sporobolus spp.) and threeawns (Aristida spp.). Shrubs are uncommon but those that occur include Yucca glauca, Ephedra torreyi, and four-wing saltbush (Atriplex canescens). Herbaceous plants include Plantago purshii, Hymenopappus filifolius, and globe mallows (Sphaeralcea spp.).
,

Location: South Gate is the major entry point onto the southeast side of the Sevilleta NWR. Just north of the gate is Met Station 41. Research here has included a Gunnison's prairie dog reintroduction as well as re-sampling of historic BLM 1976 vegetation transects, and juniper-creosote distribution. Vegetation is highly impacted by historical cattle grazing and is sparse. Burro grass (Scleropogon brevifolius) is dominant.siteid: 11

Location: The Cerro Montosa Pinyon-Juniper site has been the location of major Sevilleta LTER research since 1989. Meteorological trends, net primary productivity, rodent and ground-dwelling arthropod populations, mycorrhizal responses to fertilizer, pinyon-juniper fruit and nut production, and pinyon mortality are all being investigated at this site. Previous studies have included analyses of pinyon tree rings for regional climate reconstruction.Vegetation: The vegetation is New Mexico Pinyon-Juniper Woodland, dominated by Colorado pinyon (Pinus edulis) and one-seed juniper (Juniperus monosperma), and accompanied by gray oak (Quercus grisea). There is a diverse shrub component, including scrub live oak (Q. turbinella), mountain mahogany (Cercocarpus montanus), broom snakeweed (Gutierrezia sarothrae), sacahuista (Nolina microcarpa), red barberry (Mahonia haematocarpa), Apache plume (Fallugia paradoxa), tree cholla (Opuntia imbricata), skunkbush (Rhus trilobata), and banana yucca (Yucca baccata). Grass diversity is also high, and open spaces between trees are dominated by blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis), with hairy and sideoats grama (B. hirsuta and B. curtipendula) and black grama (B. eriopoda) also being significant. Other common grasses include purple threeawn (Aristida purpurea), wolftail (Lycurus phleoides), mountain and ring muhly (M. montanus and M. torreyi), and New Mexican porcupinegrass (Heterostipa neomexicana). Common forbs include small-flowered milkvetch (Astragalus nuttallianus), white sagebrush (Artemesia ludoviciana), Fendler’s arabis (Arabis fendleri), Fendler’s sandmat (Chamaesyce fendleri), New Mexico thistle (Cirsium neomexicanum), false pennyroyal (Hedeoma oblongifolia), bastard sage (Eriogonum wrightii), pingüe rubberweed (Hymenoxys richardsonii), large four o’clock (Mirabilis multiflora), Fendler's penstemon (Penstemon fendleri), and globemallows (Sphaeralcea hastulata and S. wrightii). ,

Location: This site is located in the foothills of the Sierra Ladrones on the west side of the Sevilleta NWR. Red Tank is a man-made earthen drainage pool and is the location of Met Station 43. Research conducted at the site includes soil moisture and erosion studies related to the Sierra Ladrone watershed project.Vegetation: The woody vegetation in this stream bed includes juniper (Juniperus monosperma), Brickellia californica, Apache plume (Fallugia paradoxa). On the hills are Junipers and shrubs such as cane cholla (Opuntia imbricata), beargrass (Nolina microcarpa), and Oreganillo (Aloysia wrightii). The herbs in the washes include Lesquerella ovalifolia, and Mirabilis multiflora. The grasses found at this site include three-awn (Aristida sp.), fluff-grass Erioneuron pulchellum, and four species of grama grass (Bouteloua spp.). , siteid: 12

Location: The Rio Salado is an ephemeral tributary of the Rio Grande on the west side of the Sevilleta NWR, flowing west by northwest to east by southeast. Rio Salado Grassland and Rio Salado Larrea are two study sites established in 1989. These sites were established as counterparts to sites at Five Points. Between 1989 and 1998, vegetation, litter decomposition, and ground dwelling arthropod and rodent populations were studied at both sites. Core studies at these sites were largely terminated in 1998, although rodent populations are still monitored at the Rio Salado Larrea site as the Small Mammal Exclosure Study's Larrea plots are co-located there. Rio Salado Grassland is the location of Met Station 44. The Rio Salado study sites are accessed by taking the San Acacia exit, going west and then taking the frontage road back north to the Sevilleta NWR gate. After entering the refuge turn left after 0.2 mi and take this road 1.4 mi to a "T" in the road at the power lines. An earthen berm stops road travel here and the met station is located about 300 m west on the blocked road. Vegetation: The Rio Salado Grassland site is Plains-Mesa Sand Scrub habitat characterized by stabilized deep-sand dominated by coppice dunes of honey mesquite (Prosopis glandulosa). Co-dominant shrubs are sand sagebrush (Artemesia filifolia) and fourwing saltbush (Atriplex canescens), with winterfat (Krascheninnikovia lanata), Mormon tea (Ephedra torreyana), broom indigobush (Psorothamnus scoparius), soapweed yucca (Yucca glauca), and broom snakeweed (Gutierrezia sarothrae) as other notable shrubs. One-seed juniper (Juniperus monosperma) is present as well, especially along shallow washes. Compared to the Black Grama Core Site, grass cover is sparse and dominated by poverty threeawn (Aristida divaricata), Indian ricegrass (Oryzopsis hymenoides), mesa and spike dropseed (Sporobolus cryptandrus and S. contractus), as well as patches of black grama (Bouteloua eriopoda). Notable forbs included spectaclepod (Dimorphocarpa wislizenii), tansy aster (Machaeranthera tanacetifolia), desert marigold (Baileya multiradiata), Abert buckwheat (Eriogonum abertianum), dwarf gilia (Ipomopsis pumila), rattlesnake weed (Chamaesyce albomarginata), blunt tansymustard (Descarania obtusa), plains hiddenflower (Cryptantha crassisepala), and Rocky Mountain zinnia (Zinnia grandiflora)., siteid: 13
Location: Bronco Well is located near the northern boundary of the Sevilleta NWR, approximately four miles west of the ATandT on the road to Red Tank.siteid: 14

Location: This station is located at the top of North Peak atop the Magdalena Mountains in Central New Mexico. The vegetation is mixture of Spruce/fir and Alpine meadows. The station is set atop a building of the Langmuir Lightning Lab.Vegetation: Spruce and Fir, siteid: 67

para.literalLayout: To monitor meteorological conditions across the Sevilleta and surrounding areas through time.

************************ CHANGE LOG *****************************************24 Mar 1991. Station 46. Vectored Windspeed data corrected for period 06 Dec 90 (hr 10) to 31 Dec 90 (hr 24) as follows: If Vectored Windspeed more or equal than 0.44704 then new_val = ((old_val - 0.44704) / 0.26666) * 0.8 + 0.44704 Else new_val = old_val This correction is made for the problem mentioned in the 08 Mar 1991 Log entry below for station 46. ***NOTE*** again that since the individual sample vectors are not available this correction is rough at best with exact ERROR unknown. 08 Mar 1991. Station 46. Average, Maximum, and Minimum Windspeed data corrected for period 06 Dec 90 (hr 10) to 31 Dec 90 (hr 24) as follows: new_val = ((old_val - 0.44704) / 0.26666) * 0.8 + 0.44704 This correction was made because it was discovered that a calibration constant of 0.26666 (instead of 0.8) was being used to calculate windspeed in the datalogger program. ***NOTE*** that the Vectored Windspeed, Wind Direction, and Standard Deviation of Wind Direction data were not corrected because they are calculated from the mean vector for the hour (i.e., the mean of 1200 vectors). Thus these data fields have an unknown ERROR. G.S.22 Jan 1991. Station 46. Changed Soil Moisture and Soil Temperature fields from 0.0 to missing values (-999) for hour 13 of 11 Dec 90 since these variables are not collected by this station but datalogger had outputted 0 values. G.S.18 Jan 1991. Station 40. All data was lost during period 05 Dec 90 (hr 13) to 31 Dec 90 (hr 24) due to datalogger malfunction. Thus all observations for this period contain missing values. G.S18 Jan 1991. Station 41. Replaced all fields with missing values (-999) for hour 15 of 05 Dec 90 due to installation of new datalogger program. G.S.18 Jan 1991. Station 42. Replaced all fields with missing values (-999) for hour 11 of 05 Dec 90 due to installation of new datalogger program. Replaced Max Solar Rad value with missing value for hour 12 of 05 Dec 90 - Bad Value. Replaced Precipitation values with missing values for period 19 Dec 90 (hr 21) to 31 Dec 90 (hr 24) due to rain gauge being tipped over. G.S.18 Jan 1991. Station 43. Replaced all fields with missing values (-999) for hour 14 of 03 Dec 90 due to installation of new datalogger program. Replaced Max Solar Rad value with missing value for hour 15 of 03 Dec 90 - Bad Value. Zeroed out precip field for hour 15 of 03 Dec 90 to remove test tips. Replaced all Vapor Pressure and RH observations for period 03 Dec 90 (hr 14) to 04 Dec 90 (hr 12) with missing values due to bugs in new datalogger program. Replaced Max Solar Rad value with missing value for hour 13 of 04 Dec 90 - Bad Value. G.S.18 Jan 1991. Station 44. Replaced all fields with missing values (-999) for hour 11 of 03 Dec 90 due to installation of new datalogger program. Replaced Max Solar Rad value with missing value for hour 12 of 04 Dec 90 - Bad Value. Replaced all Vapor Pressure and RH observations for period 03 Dec 90 (hr 11) to 04 Dec 90 (hr 11) with missing values due to bugs in new datalogger program. G.S.18 Jan 1991. Station 45. Replaced all fields with missing values (-999) for hour 13 of 03 Dec 90 due to installation of new datalogger program. Zeroed out precip field for hour 14 of 03 Dec 90 to remove test tips. Replaced all Vapor Pressure and RH observations for period 03 Dec 90 (hr 13) to 04 Dec 90 (hr 13) with missing values due to bugs in new datalogger program. G.S.18 Jan 1991. Station 46. All data was lost during period 06 Dec 90 (hr 10) to 11 Dec 90 (hr 12) due to datalogger malfunction. Thus all observations for this period contain missing values. Replaced Average, Max, Min, Vectored Windspeed variables with missing values if Max Windspeed field value was 0.447 m/sec during period 06 Dec 90 (hr 10) to 31 Dec 90 (24) since anemometer froze. *** NOTE *** This potentially affects the accuracy of the vectored Wind Direction field as well; thus this field may have some unknown ERROR. G.S20 Dec 1990. KEYWORDS Added. G.S.19 Dec 1990. Station 40-46. Modified the file format and data values for the following time periods: - station 40: 01 Jan 90 (hr 1) - 05 Dec 90 (hr 12) - station 41: 01 Jan 90 (hr 1) - 05 Dec 90 (hr 14) - station 42: 01 Jan 90 (hr 1) - 05 Dec 90 (hr 10) - station 43: 01 Jan 90 (hr 1) - 03 Dec 90 (hr 13) - station 44: 01 Jan 90 (hr 1) - 03 Dec 90 (hr 10) - station 45: 01 Jan 90 (hr 1) - 03 Dec 90 (hr 12) - station 46: 01 Jan 90 (hr 1) - 06 Dec 90 (hr 09) The following modifications were made: 1. Removed the Mixing Ratio column. 2. Added columns for Max Air Temp, Min Air Temp, Vapor Pressure, Max Solar Radiation, Min Solar Radiation. Note that these columns are filled with missing values (-999) since these variables were not collected prior to the above time periods. 3. Converted units of measure for Average Windspeed, Vectored Windspeed, Max Windspeed, and Min Windspeed from miles per hour (mph) to meters per second (m/sec). The conversion formula used was: mph * 0.44704 = m/sec. 4. Converted units of measure for Solar Radiation from kilowatts per square meter (kw/m^2) to Joules per square centimeter (J/cm^2). The conversion formula used was: kw/m^2 * 359.502 = J/cm^2. G.S.17 Dec 1990. Station 45. Zeroed out precipitation for hour 18 of day 02 Jul 90 due to test tips for calibration purposes. G.S.17 Dec 1990. Station 42. Zeroed out precipitation for hour 16 of day 02 Jul 90 due to test tips for calibration purposes. G.S.07 Dec 1990. Station 45. On 9 Nov 90 (hr 14) a field technician attempted to reprogram the data logger (to correct the problems listed in the 07 Dec 90 entry below), but misunderstood directions and thus was unable to compile the program. Thus for the period 9 Nov 90 (hr 14) through 12 Nov 90 (hr 11), there were no hourly observations for this station. All observations have missing values (-999) for this time period. G.S.07 Dec 1990. Station 45. Power loss changing batteries on 5 Nov 90 (hr 16) so all variables are -999 for this hour. During reprogramming the precipitation calibration factor was set to .28 mm/tip (instead of .2716), the atmospheric pressure constant was set to 845 (instead of 829) and the 10cm soil temperature data collection routine was mis-programmed. Thus, for the period 5 Nov 90 (hr 16) through 9 Nov 90 (hr 12), the precip data was corrected (using the procedure outlined in entry 15 Aug 90 of this file), the 10cm soil temperature observations were replaced with missing values (-999), and the mixing ratio data was not corrected (because this variable is to be deleted from this database in the future). G.S.05 Dec 1990. Station 46. Replaced all variables' values with missing values (-999) for hours 12-14 of 22 Oct 1990 due to station maintenance during this period. Also zeroed out the precipitation value for 25 Oct 1990 (hour 14) to eliminate test tips. G.S.05 Dec 1990. Stations 46. Adjusted precipitation as described under 15 Aug 1990 log (with exception that the old calibration factor for station was 5.155 ml per tip), for the following period: stn46_fac = 0.1000: 31 Aug (hr 17) - 25 Oct (hr 10) G.S.05 Dec 1990. Stations 40-42. Modified datalogger programs on these stations on 05 Dec 90 (hr 13 - stn 40; hr 15 - stn 41; hr 11 - stn 42), to effect the same program changes listed in the 03 Dec 90 entry for stations 43-45. G.S.04 Dec 1990. Stations 43-45. Fixed bugs in new datalogger programs on 04 Dec 90 (hr 13 - stn 43; hr 12 - stn 44; hr 14 - stn 45). See database correction entries later in this Change Log. G.S.03 Dec 1990. Stations 43-45. Modified datalogger programs on these stations on 03 Dec 90 (hr 14 - stn 43; hr 11 - stn 44; hr 13 - stn 45), to effect the following changes: 1. Added variables Max Air Temperature, Min Air Temperature, Vapor Pressure (in mbar units), Max Solar Flux, and Min Solar Flux. 2. Deleted variable Mixing Ratio. 3. Changed units of measure for the following: a. Wind speeds from mph to m/sec b. Solar flux from kw/m^2 to J/cm^2 G.S.05 Nov 1990. Stations 40-44. Changed RH/Air Temperature Chip on these stations on 05 Nov 90 (hr 14 - stn 40; hr 16 - stn 41; hr 12 - stn 42; hr 16 - stn 43; hr 12 - stn 44). G.S.25 Oct 1990. Station 46. Changed datalogger program on 25 Oct 1990 (hour 11) to use a precipitation calibration factor of 0.1000 mm per tip on tipping bucket rain gauge. G.S.09 Oct 1990. Stations 43 - 45. Adjusted precipitation as described under 15 Aug 1990 log, only this time for the following periods: stn43_fac = 0.3103: 03 Sep (hr 14) - 04 Oct (hr 11) stn44_fac = 0.3267: 03 Sep (hr 10) - 04 Oct (hr 09) stn45_fac = 0.2716: 03 Sep (hr 15) - 04 Oct (hr 13) G.S.05 Oct 1990. Stations 40 - 44. Changed RH chip at these stations on following hours: stn 40 - hr 14; stn 41 - hr 16; stn 42 - hr 12; stn 43 - hr 15; stn 44 - hr 11. G.S.04 Oct 1990. Station 45. Changed datalogger program on 04 Oct 1990 (hour 14) to use a precipitation calibration factor of 0.2716 mm per tip on tipping bucket rain gauge. G.S.04 Oct 1990. Station 44. Changed datalogger program on 04 Oct 1990 (hour 10) to use a precipitation calibration factor of 0.3267 mm per tip on tipping bucket rain gauge. G.S.04 Oct 1990. Station 43. Changed datalogger program on 04 Oct 1990 (hour 12) to use a precipitation calibration factor of 0.3103 mm per tip on tipping bucket rain gauge. G.S.25 Sep 1990. Stations 40 - 45. Adjusted precipitation as described under 15 Aug 1990 log, only this time for the following periods: stn40_fac = 0.2882: 01 Aug (hr 9) - 07 Sep (hr 9) stn41_fac = 0.2906: 03 Aug (hr 12)- 07 Sep (hr 11) stn42_fac = 0.3090: 08 Feb (hr 9) - 07 Sep (hr15) stn43_fac = 0.3103: 02 Aug (hr 12)- 03 Sep (hr 13) stn44_fac = 0.3267: 02 Aug (hr 9) - 03 Sep (hr 9) stn45_fac = 0.2716: 02 Aug (hr 13)- 03 Sep (hr 14) G.S.07 Sep 1990. Station 42. Changed datalogger program on 07 Sep 1990 (hour 16) to use a precipitation calibration factor of 0.3090 mm per tip on tipping bucket rain gauge. G.S.07 Sep 1990. Station 41. Changed datalogger program on 07 Sep 1990 (hour 12) to use a precipitation calibration factor of 0.2906 mm per tip on tipping bucket rain gauge. G.S.07 Sep 1990. Station 40. Changed datalogger program on 07 Sep 1990 (hour 10) to use a precipitation calibration factor of 0.2882 mm per tip on tipping bucket rain gauge. G.S.31 Aug 1990. Weather station #46 installed at Langmuir Labs in the Magdalena Mountains. First (complete) hourly observation recorded at hour 17. This station collects all variables except soil temperature and soil moisture data. The precipitation calibration factor is 5.155 ml per tip (Note that this calibration was accidently set to give volume per tip instead of depth per tip; this was corrected later). Location: Langmuir Site: Lat. 33.97472 Long. -107.1808 GS.15 Aug 1990. Stations 40 - 45. Adjusted all precipitation observations to reflect new calibration data. The algorithm used attempts to retrieve another significant digit by first converting the old ppt. figure to number_of_tips (rounding to nearest integer), then generating the new ppt. by multiplying the number of tips by the new calibration factor. The old calibration factor was 0.0254 cm per tip. Note that the unit of measure was also changed from cm to mm. For example (using station 40): 0.077cm / 0.0254cm per tip = 3.031 tips, which rounds to 3 tips, then 3 tips * 0.2882 mm per tip = 0.8646 mm ppt. The new calibration factors used are (mm per tip): stn40_fac = 0.2882: 01 Jan (hr 1) - 01 Aug (hr 9) stn41_fac = 0.2906: 01 Jan (hr 1) - 03 Aug (hr 12) stn42_fac = 0.3090: 01 Jan (hr 1) - 08 Feb (hr 9) 0.5686: 08 Feb (hr 10) - 08 Mar (hr 10) 0.6919: 08 Mar (hr 11) - 05 Apr (hr 13) 0.8155: 05 Apr (hr 14) - 27 Apr (hr 14) 0.4559: 27 Apr (hr 15) - 09 May (hr 15) 0.3090: 09 May (hr 16) - 01 Aug (hr 13) stn43_fac = 0.3103: 01 Jan (hr 1) - 02 Aug (hr 12) stn44_fac = 0.3267: 01 Jan (hr 1) - 02 Aug (hr 9) stn45_fac = 0.2716: 01 Jan (hr 1) - 02 Aug (hr 13) G.S.14 Aug 1990. Station 44. Tightened connections on datalogger side for 10 cm soil temperature sensor. This seems to have corrected the problem of intermittent invalid readings for this sensor. G.S.02 Aug 1990. Stations 40 - 44. Adjusted all precipitation observations by a constant multiplier (station specific) in order to correct for mis-calibration of rain gauges. The following correction factors were used: Station Factor Period 40 0.702 01 Jan - 08 Jan 90 41 0.699 01 Jan - 08 Jan 90 42 0.707 01 Jan - 08 Jan 90 43 0.700 01 Jan - 06 Jan 90 44 0.579 01 Jan - 06 Jan 90 This correction effectively changes the the calibration for all stations to 0.0254 cm per tip for the above shown period. Note that the datalogger programs were modified (see earlier log entries in this file) on the ending dates of the above periods to use the new calibration factor of 0.0254 cm/tip. G.S.17 Jul 1990. Station 44. Zeroed out precipitation for hour 8 of day 3 Jul 90 due to test tips for calibration purposes. G.S.17 Jul 1990. Station 43. Zeroed out precipitation for hour 12 of day 3 Jul 90 due to test tips for calibration purposes. G.S.17 Jul 1990. Station 41. Zeroed out precipitation for hour 10 of day 2 Jul 90 due to test tips for calibration purposes. G.S.17 Jul 1990. Station 40. Zeroed out precipitation for hour 14 of day 2 Jul 90 due to test tips for calibration purposes. G.S.11 May 1990. Station 40. Soil temperature sensor at 1 cm depth changed (replaced 107 probed with 108 probe) on hour 16 of day 11 May 90. G.S.11 May 1990. Station 41. Soil temperature sensor at 10 cm depth changed (replaced 108 probed with 107 probe) on hour 13 of day 11 May 90. Also removed the 10 cm and 30 cm soil moisture blocks at this station. G.S.10 May 1990. Station 45. Soil temperature sensor at 1 cm depth changed (replaced 107 probed with 108 probe) on hour 11 of day 10 Apr 90. Replaced 1 cm reading with missing value (-999) for this hour. Also replaced 10 cm temperature reading and 10 cm soil moisture reading with missing values due to bad readings caused by temporarily disconnecting wires. G.S.10 May 1990. Station 42. Zeroed out precipitation for hour 15 of day 27 Apr 90 due to test tips conducted on newly replaced tipping bucket rain gauge changed. G.S05 Apr 1990. Station 42. Added soil moisture sensors to collect data on soil moisture at 10 cm and 30 cm depths. First valid reading at hour 14 on 05 Apr 1990; all previous observations were replaced with missing values (-999). G.S.05 Apr 1990. Station 43. Added soil moisture sensors to collect data on soil moisture at 10 cm and 30 cm depths. First valid reading at hour 11 on 05 Apr 1990; all previous observations were replaced with missing values (-999). G.S.29 Mar 1990. Station 44. Added soil moisture sensors to collect data on soil moisture at 10 cm and 30 cm depths. First valid reading at hour 17 on 29 Mar 1990; all previous observations were replaced with missing values (-999). G.S.29 Mar 1990. Station 40. Added soil moisture sensors to collect data on soil moisture at 10 cm and 30 cm depths. First valid reading at hour 12 on 29 Mar 1990; all previous observations were replaced with missing values (-999). G.S.20 Mar 1990. Station 41. Added soil moisture sensors to collect data on soil moisture at 10 cm and 30 cm depths. First valid reading at hour 16 on 20 Mar 1990; all previous observations were replaced with missing values (-999). G.S.08 Mar 1990. Station 44. Replaced avg windspeed, max windspeed, min windspeed, vectored windspeed, wind direction, and std dev of wind direction fields with missing values (-999) for hour 14 of 08 Mar 1990 since these fields had invalid values. G.S.13 Feb 1990. Station 40. Replaced wind vane and anemometer sensors, because these sensors have been giving invalid readings on an intermittent basis. Therefore, changes to data base file are: replaced windspeed and direction variables with missing values (-999) according to the following conditions: (1) If max_windspeed == 1, replace avg_windspeed, min_windspeed, max_windspeed, vectored_windspeed, wind_direction, and std_dev_wind_direction with missing values. (2) If std_dev_wind_direction

The data were recorded and stored by a Campbell Scientific CR10 Datalogger. Samples were taken every "n" seconds and values averaged for the hour (where n = 3 seconds for wind speed, wind direction, and solar radiation variables; n = 30 seconds for rh, air temperature, soil temperature, and mixing ratio variables; n = 300 seconds for soil moisture variables). Numbers were stored and processed in the datalogger in binary format with 23 bit precision. Final output was rounded to a maximum of 3 decimal digits.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Station ID Number
The year in which the data were collected.
Interval of time in days since the beginning of the year. Day of the year data collected.
Hour data logged in Military Time. Time basis is Mountain Standard Time.
Sensor hgt. at 2.5 m until 14 Feb 1989 (hour 10). Thereafter, sensor hgt. at 2 m.
Maximum air temperature measured during hour
Minimum air temperature measured during hour
Mean Relative Humidity. Sensor height is 2.5 m until 14 Feb 1989 (hour 10). Thereafter, sensor hgt. at 2 m.
Average of windspeed observations over the hour. Sensor height 3m.
Mean vectored windspeed during the hour. Sensor height is 3m.
Mean wind direction vector for the hour. Sensor height is 3 m.
Standard deviation of wind direction. Sensor height is 3 m.
Maximum wind speed measured during the hour. Sensor height is 3m.
Minimum wind speed recorded for the hour. Sensor height is 3m.
Mean Soil Temperature at 1 cm
Mean soil temperature at 10 cm

Started collecting this variable in Dec 90. Vapor pressure as calculated from the relative humidyt from the 207 temp/Relative humidity sensor. Computational method for derived data: saturation vapor pressure at measured temperature times measured relative humidity
Rain gauge height at 0.5 m. Precipitation total during hour.

Note that the the values in this field are shown as positive values, but in reality are negative; thus,greater magnitudes represent drier soils. Soil moisture potential at 10 cm as measured with a gypsum block

Note that the the values in this field are shown as positive values, but in reality are negative; thus,greater magnitudes represent drier soils. Soil moisture potential at 30 cm as measured with a gypsum block.
Sensor height at 3 m. Hourly Solar Flux
Sensor hgt. at 3 m. Note: started collecting this variable in Dec 90. Maximum Solar radiation reading during hour.

ns2:unit.name: percent
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as percent composition (1:100)
